body: Thanks for taking the time to report this issue.

The issue is that when gathering the fields to compare AssertJ ignores any fields from classes in `java.lang` to avoid comparing `Object`, this is a bit too drastic, I don't remember if there was another reason (the code comes from Fest Assert the project AssertJ is based on), anyway this should be changed.
@agauchy would be nice to hear from you if you have time (but it's alright if you don't).

rename.from: The method isEqualToComparingFieldByFieldRecursively don't work with RuntimeException object
rename.to: The method isEqualToComparingFieldByFieldRecursively doesn't work with RuntimeException object

body: I'm leaving without milestone until we have some feedback on what to do exactly.

I have the same problem. You are right about that stack trace. In our cases we do not want to compare the stack traces. 

Still I think it would be better if the stack trace would be compared all the time instead of silently ignoring all fields from `Throwable`

issue.title: assertThat(actual).usingRecursiveComparison().ignoringAllOverriddenEquals().isEqualTo(expected) does not verify fields in a parent class

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

body:
I faced similar behavior too and in my case it was custom exception class that extends RuntimeException.
My propositions:

1. Add warning for such cases. If we have any type with parent from "java.lang" and does not have overriden or custom comparator then warning that comparing could be wrong.
2. Or add some property setting to allow counts such cases as failure.

It would be great if we could adjust AssertJ behaviour by some settings file and set custom comparator for all asserts and flag(s) to enable/disable raising warning/failure when we have type/class inherited from java.lang.* but don't have overrided equals or custom comparator.
Otherwise it's easy to forget and our test will be false green.

could you share your custom exception? 
Thinking out loud, we could add a configuration property to make comparing exceptions being recursively compared. 
Is that what you are expecting @V-ctor? 

I'm not too sure of if all exception fields are relevant for comparison though.

If you could provide a test case that would be great.
